awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Medium: Collaborative: Enabling Long-Term Security and Privacy through Retrospective Data Management
awd_abstract_narration:
Online data storage, everything from past conversations to tax returns to playdate invitations, may be retained at full fidelity for years or decades. Although the data being saved in online archives does not change, the personal and social contexts surrounding them do. Those life changes may necessitate changing or deleting stored data but, unfortunately, the vast quantity of data in users' online archives makes manual management infeasible. The goal of this project is to develop methods and tools that enable users to manage the data they have accumulated over many years, leveraging user-centered design and machine learning to partially automate the process. These tools will enable a better understanding of retrospective privacy in the context of modern long-lived online archives. They will also empower users to more effectively manage the risks embedded in these archives. The findings shared with the research community will advance discovery beyond this project. 

The understanding of user conceptualizations of security and privacy over time, as contexts change, has been stymied by a lack of broad, carefully collected datasets within this domain. This project will collect anonymized datasets, with users' permission, that enable further research in this area. The team is conducting one of the first longitudinal studies of how desired security and privacy decisions change over time. The project will also gather qualitative insights about users' perceptions of risk and utility for long-term data, as well as the acceptability of retrospective management mechanisms. Furthermore, it is not currently understood how temporality impacts the use of machine learning techniques for privacy, nor how to capture concept drift to ensure that latent threats can be identified within immense archives. These tasks require new machine learning approaches and predictive models that can both account for the temporal dimension and minimize user burden when automating archive management. Finally, the project will design and implement novel user-centered interfaces that address the currently unmet need of helping users efficiently minimize security and privacy risks in their large, long-term online archives.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Popular digital services have been a core part of modern life for decades, leading many consumers to accumulate data that they no longer need. Unfortunately, some of this forgotten-about data poses risks to security and privacy. While the decision to retain a given piece of data should be reevaluated over time, the large size of users' online archives makes manual management infeasible. This project developed novel user-centered technologies for retrospectively revisiting privacy and security decisions in two key domains: cloud file storage repositories and social media.

In the domain of cloud storage, the researchers conducted some of the first studies of what consumers perceive as sensitive about specific types of data stored in the cloud. The improved intellectual understanding this project developed about what characteristics of forgotten-about files consumers perceive as sensitive and useless enabled the creation of novel machine learning-based classifiers that automatically identify sensitive, useless data. These classifiers significantly improved upon existing approaches and baselines for discovering such data. At the same time, the project developed an improved understanding of what types of data consumers perceive as similar to other data in their cloud repositories, bootstrapping techniques for providing similarity-based recommendations based on the user's previous actions in cleaning up a file repository. To better transition these insights to practice, the project also developed and evaluated new user interfaces for surfacing this information to consumers, including new methods for grouping together related recommendations from machine learning-based classifiers.

In the domain of social media, the researchers collected a retrospective dataset that captured how users' desired privacy settings for social media posts compared to the privacy settings that were actually active for those posts. This understanding enabled the development of new classifiers for identifying social media posts from the past whose active privacy setting might not match the user's intent. As part of the project, the researchers also developed a novel taxonomy of interface affordances for modifying past social media posts, conducting an accompanying user study to understand how users perceive those affordances.

While these findings' broader impacts have implications for redesigning systems for cloud storage and social media, the project also had important broader impacts for education. Numerous students, including Ph.D. students and undergraduates, were trained in rigorous research methods, spurring careers at both U.S. companies and academic institutions.


Last Modified: 11/29/2022
Modified by: Blase Ur
